oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Management of the Invasive Shrub Amur Honeysuckle (Lonicera maackii) for the Endangered Perennial Wild Dill (Perideridia americana)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Loeb, Robert E.
Peters, Will
Ward, Steve
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: theme:invasion management
Lonicera maackii
invasive species
invasion management
Perideridia americana
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radnor Lake State Natural Area in Nashville, TN, has cedar glades that contain the endangered perennial herb wild dill [<jats:italic>Perideridia americana</jats:italic> (Nutt. ex DC.) Rchb.] and the invasive shrub Amur honeysuckle [<jats:italic>Lonicera maackii</jats:italic> (Rupr.) Herder]. This research examined whether <jats:italic>L. maackii</jats:italic> treatment in the Radnor Lake State Natural Area cedar glades is followed by an increase in <jats:italic>P. americana</jats:italic> plants. A grid of 60 adjacent 2 m by 4 m plots was placed in five cedar glades to encompass the <jats:italic>P. americana</jats:italic> population. With great care to protect <jats:italic>P. americana</jats:italic>, the annual treatment for <jats:italic>L. maackii</jats:italic> was to pull plants â‰¤1-m tall from the ground; and to cut stems >1-m tall and then treat the stumps with glyphosate. The <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>-tests of means for the log natural of the number of plants in the 60 plots (significance level of P-value = 0.05) were used to compare pretreatment <jats:italic>L. maackii</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>P. americana</jats:italic> counts with posttreatment counts in 2018 and <jats:italic>P. americana</jats:italic> counts at leaf out and flowering in 2018. The <jats:italic>L. maackii</jats:italic> population was significantly smaller (P-value < 0.001) in 2018 than pretreatment at all five sites. When pretreatment in 2014 and 2015 was compared with posttreatment in 2018 for the <jats:italic>P. americana</jats:italic> populations, the increases were significant at the Cheek, Harris 2, Hideaway, and Norfleet sites, but the increase at East Hall Farm was not significant. White-tailed deer (<jats:italic>Odocoileus virginianus</jats:italic> Zimmermann) trampling was the explanation given for the decreases in <jats:italic>P. americana</jats:italic> from leaf out to flowering at all five sites in 2018. Browsing was evident only at Hideaway, which had a greater loss for <jats:italic>P. americana</jats:italic> from leaf out to flowering in 2018 than the combined losses for the Cheek, East Hall Farm, Harris 2, and Norfleet sites. The research informed the creation of adaptive management decisions regarding monitoring and treatment of the invasive species <jats:italic>L. maackii</jats:italic> for an endangered species.</jats:p>
